parsetree.*:
<root><template><title>Command</title><part><name>Comments</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="1"/><value> ofp </value></part><part><name>Game name</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name index="2"/><value>1.00</value></part><part><name>Game version</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>arg</name>=<value> local </value></part><part><name>Multiplayer Arguments</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>eff</name>=<value> global </value></part><part><name>Multiplayer Effects</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>gr1</name>=<value> Unit Control </value></part><part><name>GROUP1</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="3"/><value> Order the given unit(s) to move to the given position (without radio messages). After reaching his destination, the unit will immediately return to formation (if in a group); or order his group to form around his new position (if a group leader). Use [[doStop]] to stop units returning to formation. </value></part><part><name>DESCRIPTION</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="4"/><value> unit(s) '''doMove''' position </value></part><part><name>SYNTAX</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>p1</name>=<value> unit(s): [[Object]] or [[Array]] </value></part><part><name>PARAMETER1</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name>p2</name>=<value> position: [[Array]] - format [[Position]]</value></part><part><name>PARAMETER2</name>=<value>

</value></part><part><name index="5"/><value> [[Nothing]] </value></part><part><name>RETURNVALUE</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________
		  
</value></part><part><name>x1</name>=<value> <code>_soldier1 [[doMove]] ([[position]] _officer);</code> </value></part><part><name>EXAMPLE1</name>=<value>
</value></part><part><name>x2</name>=<value> <code>this [[doMove]] ([[getMarkerPos]] "Marker1");</code> </value></part><part><name>EXAMPLE2</name>=<value>
____________________________________________________________________________________________

</value></part><part><name index="6"/><value> [[commandMove]], [[setDestination]], [[moveTo]], [[move]], [[addWaypoint]] </value></part><part><name>SEEALSO</name>=<value>

</value></part></template>

<h3 style="display:none">Notes</h3>
<dl class="command_description">

<comment><!-- Note Section BEGIN -->
</comment>
<dd class="notedate">Posted on February 9, 2008
<dt class="note">[[User:Kronzky|Kronzky]]
<dd class="note">
If doMove is to be used in conjunction with waypoint behavior commands (e.g. [[setSpeedMode]]), then those have to be issued ''after'' the move command to have an effect. Otherwise the move will be done with the default settings.


<dd class="notedate">Posted on February 3, 2009
<dt class="note">[[User:General_Barron|General Barron]]
<dd class="note">
If a unit is part of a group, and is not the leader, the unit will fall back into formation soon after the domove is completed. This does not happen for units that are in a group alone (because they are their own leader).
There is no single command to get a unit to move to a position and stay there. The best way to do this is to issue a domove, then wait for the unit to reach his destination, then disable his movement AI. VBS2 users can use the [[fn_vbs_doMoveEx_(VBS2)|fn_vbs_doMoveEx]] function.
<comment><!-- Note Section END -->
</comment>

</dl>
